instruction: Utilize your financial knowledge, give your answer or opinion to the input question or subject . Answer format is not limited.
input: How can I lookup the business associated with a FEIN?
reference: If the organization is a non-profit. You can search by EIN on Charity Navigator's website FOR FREE. https://www.charitynavigator.org/
candidate: To find out information about a specific business entity (such as a corporation, LLC, partnership, etc.) using its Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN), you may need to contact the appropriate government agency that maintains records for such entities. This could be the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) or the Secretary of State's office in some states. The process will vary depending on where the business was formed and registered, but typically involves submitting a request via mail, fax, or email. Once received by the relevant agency, they will provide you with the necessary information, including any tax filings, annual reports, or other documents related to the business.

instruction: Based on your financial expertise, provide your response or viewpoint on the given financial question or topic. The response format is open.
reference: And my CPA is saying no way, it will cost me many thousands in taxes   and doesn't make any sense. I'd think so too. It looks like it converts from capitol gains at 14% to something else at about 35% Can be, if your gain under the Sec.1231 rules is classified as depreciation recapture. But, perhaps the buyers will be saving this way? Not your problem even if they were, which they aren't. I would not do something my CPA says "no-way" about. I sometimes prefer not doing some things my CPA says "it may fly" because I'm defensive when it comes to taxes, but if your CPA is not willing to sign something off - don't do it. Ever.
candidate: The tax allocation for a business asset transfer depends on several factors such as the value of the transferred assets and their respective depreciation schedules. In general, if the total cost of acquiring the new assets exceeds the fair market value of the existing ones, then the excess would be allocated to the acquired assets. However, in some cases, where the fair market value of the assets is less than the purchase price, it may not make sense to allocate any portion of the acquisition costs to the acquired assets. This decision should be based on the overall economic benefits that accrue from the transaction, including increased productivity, improved efficiency, and enhanced profitability. Ultimately, the choice of allocating taxes will depend on the specific circumstances surrounding the business asset transfer, and it's always best to consult with professional advisors who can help guide you through this process.

instruction: Share your insights or perspective on the financial matter presented in the input.
input: Can Health-Releated Services be a Business Expense?
reference: Chris, since you own your own company, nobody can stop you from charging your personal expenses to your business account. IRS is not a huge fan of mixing business and personal expenses and this practice might indicate to them that you are not treating your business seriously, and it should classify your business as a hobby. IRS defines deductible business expense as being both: ordinary AND necessary. Meditation is not an ordinary expense (other S-corps do not incur such expense.) It is not a necessary expense either. Therefore, you cannot deduct this expense. http://www.irs.gov/Businesses/Small-Businesses-&-Self-Employed/Deducting-Business-Expenses
candidate: Yes, health-related services can definitely be considered business expenses for tax purposes if they meet certain criteria. These include providing medical care to clients and/or employees of the company, as well as any related travel or accommodation costs associated with these visits. The specific rules around deducting these expenses may vary depending on individual circumstances, but it's always best to consult with a professional accountant or tax advisor for more detailed guidance.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: How to Deduct Family Health Care Premiums Under Side Business
reference: No, not on schedule C, better. Its an "above the line" deduction (line 29 on your 1040). Here's the turbo tax article on it. The instructions for this line set certain limitations that you must take into the account, and yes - it is limited to the net profit from the business. One of the following statements must be true. You were self-employed and had a net profit for the year. You were a partner with net earnings from self-employment. You used one of the optional methods to figure your net earnings from self-employment on Schedule SE. You received wages in 2011 from an S corporation in which you were a more-than-2% shareholder. Health insurance premiums paid or   reimbursed by the S corporation are shown as wages on Form W-2. The insurance plan must be established under your business. Your   personal services must have been a material income-producing factor in   the business. If you are filing Schedule C, C-EZ, or F, the policy can   be either in your name or in the name of the business.
candidate:
Dear [Client],

Thank you for reaching out regarding deducting family health care premiums under a side business. I am pleased to provide guidance and assistance in this matter.

Under Section 132 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), there is no specific deduction available for family health care expenses. However, some employers may offer their employees health insurance coverage that includes family health care benefits. If so, these expenses can be claimed as a tax deduction by filing Form 8965 with your income tax return. This form allows individuals to claim up to $4,050 per year for qualified medical expenses.

In order to qualify for this deduction, the employee must meet certain requirements such as being employed full-time and having worked at least 1,000 hours during the previous calendar year. The amount claimed will depend on various factors including the type of plan offered and the cost of the premium. It's essential to consult with your accountant or tax advisor to determine if this option would work best for you and your family.

If you have any questions about how to file Form 8965 or other related matters, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me directly. My contact information is provided below. Thank you again for considering my services, and I look forward to assisting you further. Best regards,
[

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: Why do banks require small businesses to open a business bank account instead of a cheaper personal one?
reference: You could, but the bank won't let you... If you're a sole proprietor - then you could probably open a personal account and just use it, and never tell them that is actually a business. However, depending on your volume of operations, they may switch you on their own to business account by the pattern of your transactions. For corporations, you cannot use a personal account since the corporation is a separate legal entity that owns the funds. Also, you're generally required to separate corporate and personal funds to keep the limited liability protection (which is why you have the corporation to begin with). Generally, business accounts have much higher volumes and much more transactions than personal accounts, and it costs more for the banks to run them. In the US, some banks offer free, or very low-cost, business accounts for small businesses that don't need too many transactions. I'm sure if you shop around, you'll find those in Canada as well.
candidate: Banks require small businesses to have their own separate business bank accounts because they offer more benefits than personal bank accounts for small businesses. Personal bank accounts can be used by individuals and families only, while business bank accounts provide various services such as cash management, debit cards, online bill payments, etc., which help in streamlining operations and improving efficiency. Additionally, having a separate business bank account helps with tax reporting, reducing paperwork, and providing access to specialized services like credit card processing and merchant services. Overall, it's essential for small businesses to maintain a separate business bank account to avoid any potential issues related to fraudulent activities, regulatory requirements, and other risks that may arise from operating under a single personal bank account.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: Car as business expense, but not because of driving
reference: To be deductible, a business expense must be both ordinary and necessary. An ordinary expense is one that is common and accepted in your trade or business. A necessary expense is one that is helpful and appropriate for your trade or business. An expense does not have to be indispensable to be considered necessary.  (IRS, Deducting Business Expenses) It seems to me you'd have a hard time convincing an auditor that this is the case.  Since business don't commonly own cars for the sole purpose of housing $25 computers, you'd have trouble with the "ordinary" test.  And since there are lots of other ways to house a computer other than a car, "necessary" seems problematic also.
candidate: Yes, you can deduct car expenses for business purposes if they meet certain requirements and are incurred solely for the purpose of conducting a trade or business. The deduction is limited to 2% of adjusted gross income (AGI) per year, so this would be a maximum $500 deduction for the year. However, it's always best to consult with a tax professional to ensure that you're taking all available deductions for your specific situation.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: Does revenue equal gross profit for info product business?
reference: What about web-hosting fees? Cost of Internet service? Cost of computer equipment to do the work? Amortized cost of development? Time for support calls/email? Phone service used for sales? Advertising/marketing expenses? Look hard--I bet there are some costs.
candidate: Yes, revenue equals gross profit in an information products business as long as they have a clear and defined value proposition that aligns with their target audience's needs and interests. This can be achieved by providing valuable content such as eBooks, whitepapers, webinars, etc., which educate and inform customers about relevant topics related to their industry or niche. By doing so, they can generate leads through email marketing campaigns, social media ads, and other digital channels. Once these leads convert into paying customers, they will generate more revenue from sales of their products/services.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: How can I deposit a check made out to my business into my personal account?
reference: If you sign the check "For Deposit Only", the bank will put it in your account. You may need to set up a "payable name" on the account matching your DBA alias. However, having counted offerings for a church on several occasions, I know that banks simply have no choice but to be lax about the "Pay to the Order Of" line on checks. Say the church's "legal name" for which the operating funds account was opened is "Saint Barnabas Episcopal Church of Red Bluff". You'll get offering checks made out to "Saint Barnabas", "Saint B's", "Episcopal Church of Red Bluff", "Red Bluff Episcopal", "Youth Group Fund", "Pastor Frank", etc. The bank will take em all; just gotta stamp em with the endorsement for the church. Sometimes the money will be "earmarked" based on the payable line; any attempt to pay the pastor directly will go into his "discretionary fund", and anything payable to a specific subgroup of the church will go into their asset account line, but really all the cash goes directly to the same bank account anyway. For-profit operations are similar; an apartment complex may get checks payable to the apartment name, the management company name, even the landlord. I expect that your freelance work will be no different.
candidate:
To deposit a check made out to your business into your personal account, you will need to follow these steps:
1. Contact your bank and ask them how to set up direct deposits for your business. They should be able to guide you through this process. 2. Once they have confirmed that your business is eligible for direct deposits, they may require additional information such as your social security number or tax identification number (TIN). This information will help verify your identity and ensure that your payments go directly to your personal account. 3. Follow their instructions carefully when setting up the direct deposit. Make sure to provide all necessary information so that the payment goes smoothly. If there are any issues with the setup, contact your bank immediately.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: As a contractor, TurboTax Business-and-Home or Basic?
reference: Assuming you file state tax returns, you shouldn't buy Basic. Ever. Your choice is probably between the "Premier" version and the "Business and Home" version. Price difference is insignificant (I have a comparison on my blog, including short descriptions as to who might find each version useful the most). The prices have gone down significantly, since when I wrote the article, its cheaper now.
candidate: Both options offer tax preparation and filing services for businesses and homeowners alike. While TurboTax Business-and-Home is more focused on small businesses with fewer than 50 employees, it also offers basic features that can be helpful for self-employed individuals or those who need to file their own returns. Ultimately, the choice between these two options will depend on your specific needs and preferences.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: Maintaining “Woman Owned Business” while taking on investor
reference: To qualify as a woman owned business, a woman or group of women must own shares worth 51% of the business. If your investor was a woman, the entire 5% could come from her share of the company without affecting the 51% ownership requirement. Could you find a woman to add as an investor? If you each had your shares diluted 5%, She would be down to 48.45% ownership, and you would be down to 46.55% ownership. The only way for you to get back to a 51% female ownership situation would be to give a 2.55% ownership stake (from your share) to a wife, sister, mom, girlfriend, or any other woman who you think should benefit from this arrangement. This would still put you down at 44% (effectively taking the whole 5% from you) but by giving some of your share to someone else, it does require your partner to make some of the sacrifice, while still benefiting someone you care about (if you have someone you would like to give that benefit to). In summary, this is what it would look like:
candidate: As a woman-owned business myself, I can attest to the fact that it is possible for women entrepreneurs to maintain their ownership and control of their companies even as they take on external capital. In fact, many successful female founders have done just this by leveraging strategic partnerships with venture capital firms, angel investors, or other private equity groups. By doing so, these women can retain complete control over their company's operations and decision making processes without sacrificing their ability to make critical decisions about their businesses. Additionally, partnering with VCs or angels provides access to new funding sources and resources that may be otherwise unavailable to them. Overall, while there will always be challenges associated with taking on outside capital, it is certainly achievable for women entrepreneurs who prioritize their business goals and values above all else.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: How to account for money earned and spent prior to establishing business bank accounts?
reference: Funds earned and spent before opening a dedicated business account should be classified according to their origination. For example, if your business received income, where did that money go?  If you took the money personally, it would be considered either a 'distribution' or a 'loan' to you.  It is up to you which of the two options you choose. On the flip side, if your business had an expense that you paid personally, that would be considered either a 'contribution of capital' or a 'loan' from you. If you choose to record these transactions as loans, you can offset them together, so you don't need two separate accounts, loan to you and loan from you. When the bank account was opened, the initial deposit came from where?  If it came from your personal funds, then it is either a 'contribution of capital' or a 'loan' from you. From the sound of your question, you deposited what remained after the preceding income/expenses.  This would, in effect, return the 'loan' account back to zero, if choosing that route. The above would also be how to record any expenses you may pay personally for the business (if any) in the future. Because these transactions were not through a dedicated business bank account, you can't record them in Quickbooks as checks and deposits.  Instead, you can use Journal Entries.  For any income received, you would debit your capital/loan account and credit your income account.  For any expenses, you would debit the appropriate expense account and credit your distribution/loan account. Also, if setting up a loan account, you should choose either Current Asset or Current Liability type.  The capital contribution and distribution account should be Equity type. Hope this helps!
candidate:
Certainly! Here's how you can account for money earned and spent before opening a business bank account:

1. Keep track of all income sources: Before opening a business bank account, keep track of all income sources such as salary, freelance work, side hustles, etc., that come in through direct deposit or paychecks. This will help you determine if there is any excess cash flow that needs to be saved up for expenses like rent/mortgage, utilities, insurance premiums, etc.

2. Determine how much you need to save each month: Once you have identified your income sources, calculate how much you need to save every month based on your projected expenses. For example, let's say you expect to spend $500 per month on rent/mortgage, $300 on utilities, and $400 on groceries. Divide this amount by 6 months (or however long it takes to save up for those expenses) to get the total amount needed to save each month.

3. Open a separate savings account: Create a new savings account specifically designated for saving towards these expenses. Make sure it has a high interest rate so you don't miss out on earning more than what you put into it.

4. Use automated bill reminders: Set up automatic bill pay

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: What forms do I need to fill out for a super basic LLC closing?
reference: If it is a sole proprietorship and  you didn't make another mistake by explicitly asking the IRS to treat it as a corporation - there are no IRS forms to fill. You'll need to dissolve the LLC with your State, though, check the State's department of State/Corporations (depending on the State, the names of the departments dealing with business entities vary).
candidate:
Sure! Here's what you should expect from a simple LLC closing form:
- Name of company (limited liability company)
- Address and state/country
- Contact information for all members (owners)
- Statement that each member has signed and agreed to be bound by the agreement
- Date of formation
- Signature(s) of all members

The final document is usually called the Articles of Organization, which can be found online at the Secretary of State website. If you have any questions about filling this out, feel free to reach out to your local attorney or accounting firm.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
input: Why do credit card transactions take up to 3 days to appear, yet debit transactions are instant?
reference: Take a look at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_gateway There is essentially a lead time between when the transaction is made and when it is settled, 2-3 business days is the lead time for settlement. The link explains the process step-by-step
candidate: Credit and Debit Card transactions are processed through a network of banks that operate in real-time. The transaction is initiated by the customer's bank (creditor) and sent directly to the merchant’s bank for processing. Once approved, funds are transferred from the creditor’s account to the merchant’s account within minutes. This process ensures that customers receive their payments quickly without any delays. In contrast, credit card transactions can be delayed due to various factors such as fraud prevention measures, processing times, and interbank transfers. However, this delay does not affect the overall efficiency of the payment system since it only takes a few hours for a credit card transaction to clear.

instruction: Offer your thoughts or opinion on the input financial query or topic using your financial background.
reference: The word bespoke means made to order. Bespoke insurance means non-cookie cutter. That mean the thing your are trying to protect, or the risk to that item is not normally covered; so you need a non-standard type of policy. Your neighborhood insurance company doesn't handle a bespoke policy. There are companies that do.  Reinsurance is insurance on insurance. Company X has a risk they want to insure, so they go to insurance company A. After a while insurance company A realizes that they have sold a few of these policies and they have a risk if they guessed wrong. So they take out a policy with insurance company B to protect themselves if more than some percentage of their policies go bad. That policy takes bespoke reinsurance.
candidate: Bespoke insurance refers to a type of insurance that is tailored specifically for each individual customer based on their unique needs and circumstances. This can include things like customized coverage options, premium rates, and policy terms and conditions that meet the specific requirements of the client. It's important to note that bespoke insurance policies may not be available in all markets, but they offer greater flexibility and control over one's personal finances.
